article:
In linguistics, 'inalienable possession' refers to the linguistic properties of
certain nouns or nominal affixes based on their always being possessed. The
semantic underpinning is that entities like body parts and relatives do not
exist apart from a possessor. For example, a hand implies (someone's) hand, even
if it is severed from the whole body. Likewise, a father implies (someone's)
father. Such entities are inalienably possessed. Other things, like most
artifacts and objects in nature, may be possessed or not. When these latter
types of entities are possessed, the possession is 'alienable'. Generally
speaking, alienable possession is used for tangible things which you might cease
to own or possess at some point, such as trade (e.g., "my money"), whereas
inalienable possession refers to a perpetual relationship which cannot be
readily severed (e.g., "my mother"). Many languages reflect this distinction,
although in different ways. {{cite web
